I love musicals. I've seen most of them both on stage, as well as in movie form if available and vice-versa. La la land felt like an intense attempt to look like an old school version super imposed on a modern day scenario, but failing miserably to produce a fraction of the emotional resonance that a musical should. The present's wrappings were spectacular, but there was nothing inside. I'm still not clear on what exactly drew the romantic leads to one another. What did they like? Passion for their individual dreams was inferred, but not exactly developed. Their love affair was even more fragile then explained by a few critics. While I got a small kick out of the inside LA references, it only served to remind me of the multitude of reasons why I can't stomach living there long term. (I grew up in LA). Everybody is jockeying for position, but substance is practically non-existent. There's a party somewhere every night of the week, and everybody is working their ass off to get that one break, but the question is Why??? Fame, fortune, visibility? Whatever happened to telling a really, really good story? To me, this was a paper thin story... kind of like modern day Hollywood. The storytellers have left the building. Only the template is left. Gorgeous sets, check. Frame for frame nods to past classics, check. Camera angles, check. Facial and body blocking shots of impossibly camera friendly actors, check. Exactly structured musical numbers with impossibly cheesy writing, check. But you forgot the substance, The profundity. They tried an Umbrellas of Cherbourg ending, but failed to recognize that Umbrellas was written in a time when people still believed in love to the point where lives were irretrievably altered and devastated if lovers didn't make it long term. You can tell nobody really believes in love like that in the movie. Not to where it alters you. It's implied, but you don't feel it. I didn't feel ANYTHING. Which is too bad, because I love Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling's acting. I just wish they had b,een given more to work with.

While watching the 2017 Oscars, I found myself wondering why Samuel L. Jackson kept rolling his eyes when the presenter announced another win for La la land.  I was behind in my Oscar viewings and had yet to see the film. "It can't be that bad" I thought in contemplation of Mr. Jackson's raised eyebrows. Having now seen the film, I must say I'm sorry Mr. Jackson. Your contention was not in vein. La la land's numerous Oscar wins may be the proof we needed to show that the Academy is overrun by a certain demographic: those who remember the 1950's and 60's with fondness, and likely shed a tear in nostalgic reminision when Ryan Gosling tapped his feet and Emma Stone squealed in delight.

Movies are supposed to be fantasy. This movie was fantasy...all the way up until the ending, when the movie decided to meet reality. The ending was basically reality. I don't watch movies to be reminded of reality. I watch movies to escape and to wander into fantasy land. This movie's ending was too similar to something that happens in real life. And for that reason, I can't give this movie more than 3 1/2 stars. 

All that said, Emma Stone is one of the greatest actresses I've ever seen. Her performance in this movie was one of the best I've ever seen. Very happy for her. Ryan Reynolds did a great job too. The movie musical is something of the past. Bygone. Dormant.
The genre's attempted revival arrived last year via Damien Chazelle in the form of alleged crowd-pleaser La La Land, a weakly conceived project whose disappointing first act flows into a second that achieves striking depths of dullness. The film's only truly magnificent scene is it's very last, meaning that the credits start rolling as soon as you've become truly engaged. 

"Another Day of Sun" kicks the film off. Rather clumsily. The song is a sprightly, uplifting ditty that ultimately has no lasting effect because it's wasted on an idiotic, messily choreographed and haphazard dance number that features nameless, curiously uncharacterized folk clumsily clamoring over traffic-halted cars in one moment and a blonde proudly flashing her undergarments in the next. It's an incredibly rough start to a dishearteningly mediocre movie.

Soon after comes the introduction of wannabe actress Mia. Her first interaction with Sebastian is an egregious, unabashed raise of the middle finger, immediately establishing her petulant, whiny, puerile mess of a character. It also doubles as a gesture to viewers who are anticipating a film that is innovative and intelligent. Mia is played laboriously by the otherwise insanely likable Emma Stone, whose inherent charms are one of La La Land's few saving graces. Ryan Gosling's performance as pianist Sebastian (or "Seb," as he's most commonly referred to as) isn't much better, and the popular actor goes on to prove through the movie's flurry of songs that he, for the life of him, can't sing or carry a tune. The only likable characters, Mia's delightful roommates, are stranded in extremely minor roles. The horribly overrated John Legend also appears, and he's forced to perform as a character even more dull and obnoxious than the two protagonists combined. He's also tasked with carrying the weight of the worst song in the entire film.

The majority of the music mostly goes to waste, which, needless to say, is a deadly mistake for a musical to make. Each song is undermined by awkward camerawork, uninspired visuals, and a general lack of inspiration. There's a nagging sense of familiarity that can't be shaken. The aptly named "Epilogue" is the only tune that avoids those four fatal attributes and it truly succeeds in making a lasting impression, along with the scene it accompanies. The conclusion is moving, well-filmed, and evocative- three things the rest of the film only wishes it was.

Perhaps the picture's greatest sin is its utter inability to deliver on it's lofty promise. La La Land is widely praised as a pure delight and return to glory for the musical genre, when it fails to qualify as either of those things. The film is not intellectually inclined and is content to deliver an unbelievably cliched and overused message: follow your dreams. Countless other movies and works of fiction have made the pursuit of one's dreams it's central theme with rocky results, and it's crystal clear that Damien Chazelle and the screenwriters did not learn from them.

The poorly drawn characters, weak writing, and the lack of a brain to go with its beating heart render La La Land a mostly unspectacular dud, unworthy of its effusive acclaim and glowing reputation. The film has noble intentions, but they never come to fruition. It's more a celebration of insecure brats that don't know how to pursue their dreams in a rational fashion than a loving homage to the Hollywood of old. A better title for this misfire would be "Blah Blah Bland."

Yet, I couldn't give La La Land 5 stars because there are just a few scenes that are so strange and you are not sure whether or not they happened, or it was just in both of their imaginations. Its really pretty and beautiful but you just say to yourself, "WTF?" Also Ryan Gosling, though a very accomplished actor, did not fit the part in my opinion. He did well, but they could have found someone better(and maybe someone who could actually sing). Overall it's great, I just have those little nitty gritty things I didn't like.
Terrible! Beyond me how this was nominated for B.P. Found it to be downright annoying. Couldn't even finish it. Turned it off after 25 minutes.

Definitely one of the most memorable pictures of 2016. I earnestly tried to find any reason to not give it a 5-star rating, just out of principle, but I couldn't. I don't like musicals but this is one of those rare examples that proves that a quality movie is beyond genres. It's also a rare example of a movie with soul, a movie that touches you deep and lingers for a long time with its majestic love story and even a drop of realism. I won't even say about technical sides of it. This movie will be remembered and loved for a long time, probably will become a classic.
Apart from the absolute perfect cinematography on the dance scenes, what's truly impressive about this film is the way the film is concluded!
could've been perfect.... if the 2 leads really knew how to sing.....  besides that.....beautiful!

This movie is amazing in every single way, from the incredible story, cinematography, directing, acting and most of all the chemistry between Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, without those two i don't think the movie would work as well. To summarise i loved this movie, and it became one of my favourites, i strongly recomend watching, I promise you will not regret it.

A display of America's self-indulgent, self-congratulatory, fatuous culture. That it has been so highly acclaimed by critics says so much about how profoundly the USA has lost its way. It's beautiful to look at, but empty of meaning. So sad.
A musical that subverted the pretentious attitude most musicals carry with nuanced performances and deep characters. Less gay than most musicals.

8/10
I'm not a big fan of romantic musical movies but LA LA LAND break the ice. The story is beautiful and my heart break at the ending. The truth between real life and dream. The soundtrack is great I really like the song "City of Stars". No doubt on 6 Oscars win. 

Who enjoy LA LA LAND will love the movie "500 Days of Summer" too. It's quite similar.

I won't be the first to start their review with this line but I don't like musicals.  Ultimately I didn't really like this one either.  I could happily watch Gosling read the phone book I think he's so talented and charismatic as an actor and he gave me my real moments of enjoyment.  The central love story is engaging and interesting, the intermittent pauses to skip around, dance and sing a little less so for me.  Like I say I'm not the target audience but whisper it quietly...the songs are terrible anyway aren't they?
Simply put - this movie wasn't for me. I gave this a chance on a 10 hour flight. Turned it off after 15 minutes. If you like these kind of movies it may hold your attention.

More successful as a love letter to not-so-young artists than as a love story, it doesn't earn its bona fides until its final chapter. I'm not convinced it needed to be a musical (because it's not a very good one), and think its script never rises to the promise of its theme and plot. Nevertheless, the more I consider what it says, and how it does the saying of it, the more affecting it becomes. In those final frames, the improvisational jamming became the melancholy song it was always destined to be. It's a trumpet blare from the soul masquerading as a candy-colored trifle.

Awful, bland musical. Two bad people who shouldn't be together upset about not being together. Female lead is unfaithful to her partner and the male lead has no personality besides liking jazz. Makes me ashamed to be straight.
love, love, love! Ryan Gosselin and Emma Stone have fireworks onscreen, the perfect duo for this wonderful, fun, musical. This one belongs in the favorites collection.
Very boring, slow pace, same song throughout the film, singing and songs are below average.
Not sure how this movie won so many awards. It was okay, cute storyline but at times I had no idea what was going on.

Being a saxophone player and having a huge passion for music, I had very high expectations for La La Land. By far, this film is one of the best of its kind. Great music, great acting, and a well developed storyline.
Devastating, but not completely unexpected ending. Amazing movie.

An absolutely gorgeous film to behold, La La Land is a spectacular piece of art with some of the best directing, cinematography, and shot composition you'll find in modern film. The story of two young people trying to make it in Hollywood is filled with romance, humor, and lots of fantastic music. What makes the film, for me, is the chemistry between Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone. The romance that buds in this film is one of the best in recent memory and the finale is surprising and deeply emotional. This is a film that fills you with joy, tugs at your heartstrings, and doesn't let you go even after you've walked away from it. Definitely a suggested watch. Even folks who don't enjoy musicals will find merit in this film.

Such a beautiful film to look at. Excellent cinematography, great direction, and stellar performances from the two leads propel this update to the classic musical. Gosling and Stone have an undeniable chemistry on screen and that puts them on the level of other classic romances.

Beautifully done movie; just prepare yourself for a slow start.  The slow beginning shouldn't take away from the movie though, sit back and enjoy a magically constructed world with stellar performances.  Without spoiling the ending, I'd say that my only real complaint about the film is the abrupt 5 years later cut at the end.  We're given a sense of how both Gosling and Stone's characters will get to where they are professionally, but what changes for Stone's personal life is a complete mystery to the viewer.
Oh man this movie is amazing all the way through. Its a beautiful film hands down, i guess the only thing i didn't like was the end.

A highly enjoyable feel-good film that focuses on the struggles of pursuing a career in the entertainment industry. The excellent music, composed by Justin Hurwitz, complimented and told the story of the film. It is particularly enjoyable for aspiring actors and musicians as it is a refreshing, unique representation of the entertainment industry, which is honest.
A simple story about falling in love that sets itself apart with terrific music and great acting.
Chazelle's assured direction plus powerful (and lovely) performances by Gosling and Stone make La La Land one of the best movies I've ever seen. And also one of the most hopeful.
After all the hype it was just ok. The parallels of Jazz as a dying breed and a musical La La Land a dying breed of film are undeniable.

A love letter to classic musicals, La La Land is a feel-good flick with brilliant leading roles from Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling.

10/10
This movie was amazing! This movie really lifted my spirits at a time when I needed it! I recommend it to anyone. The music was all fantastic and the cast was phenomenal!
This is a great way to spend a night when you want to get to bed early.
An ok story but  long and drawn out... got half way thru and was going to give up and leave but forced myself to finish watching... so 2 hrs I won't get back instead of 1

Beautiful movie that I would have been obnoxious about when I was 13.
Film is filmed beautifully, actors were good, and the songs were not annoying.

One of the best films I've seen this year, Emma Stone is fabulous.  Going down to La La Land with the family next month.

a good written story,funny,enjoyable, and im looking forward for la la land 2.

Wow!!!! Wow!!!!!   How do people like this!!!!!  It wasn't even good singing. Gosling played same song 1500 times.   Just terrible!!!!!
Very original and creative.

Hands-Down
La La Land is the Best movie of the 2010's so far

Pretty, colourful and musical, 'La La Land' is still not so new, and remains a bit of a déjà-vu in its story and theme through other films of the genre. However, it is good one: a clever film about showbiz and love like Hollywood loves them, irresistibly interpreted by Stone and Gosling and passionately directed by Chazelle. Briefly, 'La La Land' fulfills his ambition to travel back to the Golden Era of Hollywood Musicals more by recycling than recreating them. I find it a bit overrated though.

really need someone to tell me a fault in it the best exprience i have ever had in the whole year andrew garfield was my favourite preformance of the year for hacksaw tidgeuntil i saw this And ryan goseling became my favourite one so as amy adams for her preformance in Arrival till i saw this and emma stone became my favourite one c'mon give them both and goddam oscar for this movie and both songs of this movie anf they are City of stars and the fools who dream are enough to carry a whole  movie season Thank u so much Damien chazelle for writing and directing this masterpiece this movie had to win at least 11 or 14 oscar and had to win best movie and ill give it 10/10

LA LA Land is about a struggling actress played by Emma Stone who tries to make it in Los Angeles while Ryan Gosling is a struggling jazz artist who is in the same predicament.  The storyline isn't new, same crap but now it's a musical.  What can I say I am not a big a big fan of these movies all I wanted to do is bunch them in the face.  It was a mixture of all musicals into one.  It wasn't worth my time to watch this piece of crap again.

this movie starts out in your face, and you are not sure what is coming. as it progresses, it evolves. I found myself sitting tense the last 20 min or so. I knew it was a love story, I knitted or was a musical, I did not expect it to me haunting. it still make you think about life, decisions you make, and those you have loved. my husband never feel asleep. lol. she deserved her Oscar, but I think he should have gotten one too. do yourself a favor...watch it.

Reading reviews I was shocked, to see that so many people enjoyed this movie, I will admit i laughed at a full blown 2 scenes but I was yawning through the rest of the movie. I liked the charters I hated the dialog, it was like watching a really bad music video. I have seen both actors in much better roles, and loved them but this made them look bad. I don't blame them though this movie had no heart, no sentiment, it felt thoughtless and that ending like WOW! She doesn't even end up with him. I expected much more for a 'Romance Musical' and I give one star to the writer, for trying. Even though it wasn't  wow me amazing it had the potential to be.
Should have won best picture.
Meh...I did not enjoy this musical.

2.5/5-Had a lot of issues with this film.  One it was boring, two the story wasn't interesting or original, three the songs weren't memorable and the singing and dancing...well...the principle actors just aren't great singers or dancers, and four I never connected with the characters or cared about them. This movie was simply brilliant in all of its several different and unique aspects. It is a theatrical masterpiece!
Underwhelming and sadly unimaginative. Lacking in punch and enthusiasm. Missing the "Wow" factor that I've come to expect from musicals that have found critical acclaim and awards in the past.
horrible story....Emma Stone can do better, she is doing poorly in this movie.
I never imagined when I sat down to watch this that it would cause me to spend a half an hour debating the ending.
This movie was incoherent. The lead actors can barely dance or sing, and every scene felt like Ryan Gosling mansplaining jazz.

This movie is absolutely horrible.
On the plus side the music isn't bad and the dance numbers are pretty good. That said, these people would be thrown out on their bums if they tried to pass this off as theater on Broadway.
The story is simplistic and has large gaps in logic. A barista driving a newer Prius and living in a large apartment/condo? Err...what?
What really drove me nuts was the over enhanced colors and the CGI that made objects that should be blurry not and then blurring out nearby objects when something was obviously caught in the reflections. Come to think of it, I think bothers me a lot as no one else seems to have mentioned it. Do you people go outside? 
The plot is pretty thin and repetitive - not sure why they have to pound you over the head with certain film/Hollywood references.
The Volvo V60 Polestar was a quirky but kind of cool car to feature and it did look good under the neon lights. 
Overall this is a good first draft but they really needed to go back and edit the film and clean up the motion-picture photography.
I was sold and enamored with this movie after the first highway scene. Good pace, witty dialogue, great music and dance. It's just amazingly fun movie, and sure to put a smile on your face.
I was disappointed in this film after all the hype. I love old musicals and I greatly enjoyed films like Moulin Rouge, Le Miserables - but I just didn't care for this one at all.

The movie would have been even better without the musical aspect, the songs aren't memorable and felt a bit forced. It has a great story that is cliche but is executed so well on every level. The look and camera work stands way out to go along with the great chemistry between Gosling and Stone.

Apart from the cleverly repeated music that left a viewer humming, the movie felt superficial and only slightly satirical at best. The characters were hard to connect with and the ending was predictable. Even when the movie recognized the cliché of moving to Los Angeles in order to pursue a career in entertainment business, it did not dive into the subject deeper than that.
Nice music, nice plot and a good ending. Best musical after Chicago I would say

The songs were great, as were the dances. I loved the character development between Stone and Gosling, the story of the man and the woman trying to fit into society and get what they want (which they do end up getting) is great and all- until the end. They get everything they want except for each other (And the characters did actually have the power to change that but they didn't.) Really? I left the theatre mildly annoyed, and ruined for me what otherwise was such a good film.

My wife and I absolutely loved it...with life as hectic and crazy as it is these days it was nice to sit together and get lost in this wonderful musical.  The 2 main actors have fabulous voices and make an excellent on screen match.  Not many movies make you think about them the next day and think about your own world and what can you do to make it more magical too!  Perfect date movie for a Saturday night home.

I loved Lala land. I know many were disappointed with the ending, but the superb acting, amazing direction, and fantastic writing had me hooked all the way through. The ending was realistic and poignant.
Good thing Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone can sing  and dance considering this is a musical.

I don't think I need to say much here. This movie is obviously great. The musical numbers were really well thought out with most of them designed to appear as single take shots, and they all had great direction in the camera work, cinematography, timing, and choreography. Emma Stone has been my favorite actress for years now, probably since at least Zombieland and Easy A, and she really shines here and easily deserves the awards she won for the role, as do most of the people involved in this movie. While the movie takes place in modern day, it does a great job bringing the nostalgic feel of older movies and times, and this mixing of new and old plays a central role in the story as well, so it's the perfect style to tell this story in. I'm also glad to see another musical taking on the live singing approach we first saw in the new Les Misérables movie, as I think it does a lot to add to the realness of the performances, which can otherwise sometimes feel phoney during those big musical numbers. La La Land was my favorite movie of 2016, and is a classic I know I'll be watching again and again.

Personal Grade: S++
Technical Score: 98%
One of the best movie musicals EVER (OK, not THE best, but easily top 10 and probably top 5). How could you NOT love Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling?

Fun film and great songs, but it didn't live up to the hype surrounding it. This film is catered to the industry (of which i am also a part of), and both Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling have had much better performances in their careers. It portrays itself as a love letter to Los Angeles when in reality it is a giant Hollywood circle-jerk.

Forgettable characters. Forgettable songs. Inconsistent tone. Awful sound mixing. Stone's quality performance isn't enough to save a film that's average at best. The aesthetic is good, but the plot is meh.
A masterpiece... Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone give brilliant performances.  Outstanding musical score and songs.  An amazing film experience!

Bravo! Fantastic! Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone were great together! No wonder she won the Oscar. Oscar winner for best director, Damien Chazelle wrote and created very colorful, pop, bitter sweet and wonderful musical movie! I loved Whiplash too! I loved LA traffic musical opening! Absolutely it was like West Side Story! Also it reminded me Casablanca, Singin' in the Rain and lots of classic movies. Climax was fantastic! I was speechless! I loved songs, even Take on Me and I Run! Maybe John Legend was little annoying... But I had a great time! Watch it with loud surround sound!

Reluctantly and not without hesitation, I am to admit, I have finally watched this movie and found myself surprised. This movie is far from perfect but it has won me over with its imperfection, on one hand, but on the other with its poignant melancholy and deep humanity. It's not so much about a romantic musical as it is about the bittersweet taste of our lives, their impermanence and ultimately tragedy of not being able to have it all, having to compromise and make peace with what has been and won't ever be the same. Directing and acting (especially that of Stone's) are great. "A treat," as another reviewer has mentioned. "An imperfect but strangely unique" treat I would add.

Damien Chazelle brings Hollywood to life and revives some of that old studio magic in "La La Land". And from start to finish the acting, music, and cinematography are just beautiful.

The first big nod needs to go to Justin Hurwitz, who has composed an excellent modern-day musical about the struggles and magic of "La La Land". Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling shine in great performance roles that they mold into their own, never feeling like they're acting but rather let their characters leap off the screen and allow the viewer to fill in all the emotion that they are going through. Again highlighting the fantastic music and the natural performances, combined with Chazelles uses of long takes and pans takes you back to the Hollywood of old, when you needed to be a true performer (singing, dancing, acting) and gives off a stage show feel on the silver screen. 

The use of colour and light is brilliant, every shot feeling structured, planned, and well executed to provide optimum emotional value and connection to our dreamers. Again, driven by a fantastic screenplay and strong performances across the board - this is a movie that belongs in everyone's library. Especially the aspiring film makers - everything you want to learn about how to make a great film is here. Which is what makes it great - redundantly. 

All great films are teaching films. Along with being an excellent piece of nostalgic cinema with a fresh look at our modern struggles of following a dream this movie teaches young viewers how to create a great film.
Beautifully done! Wonderful homage to Southern California and Hollywood in particular. Loved the beginning and ending rolling scenes. This is one I will see and listen to again and again.

The good: very well filmed especially the final part with the what-if storyline, fun choreography and entertaining musical numbers, references to classic Hollywood, Emma Stone's acting

The bad: tired premise (Hollywood dreams, again), mansplaining, contrived and unconvincing depiction of jazz with respect to "pure" jazz vs "selling out", would have loved to see Emma Stone's character more  fleshed out like Gosling's
Such a boring storyline, only partially saved by the charm of the two leading actors.

La La Land is a charming musical that about the magic of LA and chasing dreams.  The story follows an aspiring actress and a struggling jazz musician who fall in love.  Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling both give extraordinary performance and have great chemistry together.  And the comedy is really well-done, and has a subtle and clever humor to it.  Also, the musical numbers are quite good and are integrated in a very natural way; particularly the choreography, which is incredibly creative.  However, the film kind of gets tripped up on the ending, and whether one should sacrifice love for dreams.  It's not without some flaws, but overall La La Land is touching and beautiful film.

Oh lord.  I was not expecting all that... The musical stuff is off-putting to many, but don't let that make you miss this great love story.  I myself was not thrilled with a lot of it, but I can't deny Stone and Gosling have electrifying chemistry. Didn't even realize I was pulled right into their story thanks to it. And that ending... Whoo boy!  What a kick in the heart.  Jeez!
Heartbreaking yet feel good.
Song and dance movies aren't really my thing but I guess this wasn't as bad as I anticipated it would be.
Beautiful in nearly every technical aspect, plus songs, but so vapid and predictable it would have been painful to watch without the decent sounds and sights.
This is an amazing movie. I love the music, the cast, the bright colors, but what I love the most was the end; it really was a perfect finale! Definitely an interesting screenplay.
The most exceptional film of 2016. The music, the screenplay, the direction, the cast......It's a perfect film.

I truly wanted to enjoy this film, but was very disappointed.  I love musicals and I have this strange idea that they should be performed by singers and dancers.  I respect that Ryan Gosling worked very hard so he could appear as if he were playing the piano, but his singing voice is terrible.  Emma Stone was slightly better (especially in the audition song), but not amazing.  There are better singers in the shows on cruise ships.  In the heyday of the hollywood musical, the two "stars" would have been dubbed.

Similarly, the dancing was OK, but not world-class.  

At a time when musicals are rare - why not get the best musical talent?

From the opening scene i was hooked on this movie, it was something i've never seen before and never felt before watching a movie. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling play their characters with such perfection that you forget that you are watching a movie and feel like it's all happening right in front of you. While watching this movie i at so many instances felt that what the character was feeling in that moment i could relate to that and one of the scenes when Emma Stone's character says Maybe i am not just good enough to do this and that hits a little close to home. This movie relates so well to each one of us in different ways, maybe you relate to the romantic factor of this movie, maybe the rejection factor or maybe you want to feel what its like to be in love. The music and the choreography was perfection. I cannot fault this movie for anything. Best movie of the year
If you do not like 50s musical and dancing movies, not even cinematographical references (and not the songs) can save it-but, maybe, the acting of Emma Stone, or Ryan Gosling apology about jazz.

This movie was fantastic! Ryan and Emma Killed it!

Such a beautiful, amazing movie !! It made me smile and emotional at the same time :*

I really enjoyed this. Some aspects reminded me of Gene Kelly musicals, especially an American in Pars. But the color, theme, and overall feel is a modern take on Jacques Demy's The Umbrellas of Cherbourg. It's full of bittersweet passion and playful charm.

It was okay. Honestly, I don't understand all the hype on this one. The love story wasn't all that impactful, add the randomness of the main characters breaking into a song in the middle of a conversation for no reason, makes it corny. It's like watching an Indian movie in Bollywood without subtitles. Same theme: a love story, trouble in paradise, random singing and dancing hugging a tree and running in circles while hugging the tree and singing. There's always rain out of nowhere and lots of "scenic" views when the song and dance break out. I love the actors. They're great. The actors are the reason I gave the movie 3 starts or I'd drop the rating to one star.

(2.5 stars)

Another loved movie of 2016. La La Land stars Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling. It is a musical about an actress (Emma Stone) and a musician (Ryan Gosling) who are trying to get their carriers off the ground. La La Land was a surprise for me. All it really is, is a mid-20th century musical with modern-day revisement. It was a masterpiece. This flick had some solid performances that really stood out. The use of color was noticeably good, along with some of the best lighting of that year. The story was compelling as well. I thought it was unpredictable, in a good way. La La Land is truly a game-changing film. It is in my opinion, a movie that brought back the genre.
Over all, La La land is the very definition of a love letter to Hollywood. It is by-far the best musical of recent years. 5/5 stars
The best modern musical. Will probably be known as one of the greats for the years to come.
Loved everything about "La La Land" - the music, the costumes, the set design, the acting and directing. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling are fantastic in this film. Highly recommended!!

It's not what emotions you'll feel during this journey but it's 'how' you're gonna feel them that makes it different, it's an all new way to feel. Saw this on a flight and it killed 2 hrs or so. A musical based on escapist notions of what is, what could have been and what could be. It begs the question of whether being in la la land is a good or bad thing.

While not as good as all the nominations and critical praise surrounding this movie, La La Land is still an original throwback, breathing new life into a dying genre. Damien Chazelle's ambition and skill as a director make this film the dream-like experience it is. Very few directors can handle the surreal without becoming pretentious, luckily Damien is one of them. Our leads are wonderful as singers, dancers, musicians and actors, particularly Emma Stone who gives a naturalistic and breath-taking performance. The score and soundtrack are both wonderful experiences on their own, while still remaining important to the plot of the film. The best musicals are ones that use music to foreshadow events in the story or convey a character's emotion, and this film does just that. However, what really makes this film is the cinematography. Almost every scene has expertly crafted use of colour, camera movement, choreography and detail. Because of this, you can rewatch the film several times and notice new things you didn't before, enhancing the experience. La La Land is a film that perfectly encapsulates dreams and dreamers, and the dangers that come with both.

An alternative view - I lived through the era of great song and dance movies.  This isn't one of them.  The actors are neither good singers or actors, and the story just goes on and on.  So "the journey" isn't all that great and the ending is telegraphed, so what's the hype?

I am going to try to convince you to see this fantastic movie : La La Land ! It is really one of the best film I have ever seen in my life...  So, La La Land is a musical directed in 2016 by Damien Chazelle (who won the Academy Award for Best Director) and the two lead actors are Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling.
La La Land tells the story of Mia (Emma Stone), an aspiring actress, and Sebastian (Ryan Gosling), a dedicated jazz musician who are both passionnate about dance and singing. They meet in Los Angeles and a love story is set up between the two characters. But the plot is really based on their career : their tries, their successes and mostly their failures... 
The acting is just amazing ! Well, of course Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are originally brilliant actors but in this musical, they overstep the mark and they explode the screen. Their roles are extremely difficult seeing as they have to dance and sing. It is not regular to see actors in this position. This movie is hard to play because it brushes past different genres : it is of course a musical and all the difficulties that it represents for the acting but it touches also the romance, the comedy and finally the drama genre. So I can say that the actor's performance is absolutely great ! By the bye, Emma Stone won the Academy Award for Best Actress In A Leading Role for her Mia's role in La La Land.
It seems to me very important to write some words about the film techniques... Just to precise, to the Academy Awards Ceremony, La La Land cleared out the Award for Best Original Music Score, the Award for Best Cinematography and the Award for Best Production Design ! There is something which is magic in this movie : the atmosphere. In fact, the story takes place in present days but the setting, the costumes are older : it feels like being in the United States in the 50's. It is very funny and enjoyable. What about music ? Well, of course it is the common thread of the movie. But it takes a particular place for the characters : for exemple, one of the song is often repeated by Mia and Sebastian when they are sad or demotivated... and another one is characteristic of happy moments. The movie plays also on lighting sometimes like when a spotlight is pointed at an actor so as to give a kind of theatrical effect to the scene.
Of course La La Land wants to stage actors who represents the difficulties and all the hard process to get their break in the world of theatre, cinema and music. But even if La La Land presents a dramatic aspect of this situation, the movie encourages people to have dreams and to believe in its. Furthermore, (SPOILER ALERT) in the film, the love story have not a happy ending but it allows them to progress in their carrer and to do evoluate the two characters : it is a springboard. So, La La Land is not just a superficial romance but it deals also with important topics. 
It is just gorgeous, like a flipbook made of dreamy vintage postcards that are somehow about contemporary life in Los Angeles. Chazelle's strong direction coupled with powerful performances from Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling help to create a wonderful and nostalgic treat at the cinema. I think it would be a shame to do not see La La Land seeing as it is still the most rewarded film this year !
Everything is perfect in this movie: Acting, story, score, production design, choreography and so on.

 I was quite disapointed.

   The plot is to me the stereotypical hollywood success story that tries and fails to disguise itself as an emotional acount of the rejection and sucrifice in persuit of dreams. 
   Acting-wise Gosling was good, Stone was better but undeserving of an Oscar.
   In the end it was mainly Damien Chazelle' s unconventional direction that saved this movie from being a complete dissapointment. He managed to create visually stunning compositions that are both dreamlike and emotionally impactful. Unfortunately his work is not supported by the other elements of this movie that ends up paling in comparison to his previous work 'Whiplash'.

La La Land is clearly a movie with an agenda. It sets out to resurrect the movie-musical, and to make Oscar noise. The story of La La Land (which I saw two weeks before the Oscar awards debacle) is a routine boy-meets-girl tale combined with struggling artists (she's an actor, he's a musician) trying to make it in Los Angeles. But the production and cast are spectacular. Truly innovative song and dance numbers are mesmerizing. This film has a look and feel that hearkens back to the Technicolor musicals of the '60s (I was particularly reminded of West Side Story), but with modern updates to camera technique, acting, and pacing. From what I could tell, most, if not all, of the musical numbers were recorded in a single take, including a tour de force opening number on a jam-packed freeway on-ramp. The camera swoops and glides, yet the action is always perfectly framed. Emma Stone performed powerfully, while Gosling seemed totally natural, which takes a whole other level of skill to achieve. There are a few fantasy sequences, which may confuse some people, but they showcase the director's deft handling of light and colour. This is a film for film-lovers.

La La Land is a near-perfect film with a well executed story that effectively pays tribute to movies of the 50's, but it's musical sections are mediocre and not so much of a "La La Land" than it is Bla Bla Bland. The movie would've fared better had it not been a musical. La La Land desperately needs better choreographers and more memorable songs. While it executes its simple story well with believable character development, the sections of the movie where they break into song lack energy and have you waiting for the next bit of the story to come along.

However, every other aspect of the movie is great and one thing that makes the simple story stand out is the film's excellent use of its scenery and camera to craft imagery that is not only great to look at, but has a wealth of symbolism hidden within. Every scene in the movie has an artistic attention to detail that is nothing short of poetic. La La Land is a good movie, but a mediocre musical.

While it is a bland musical, there are a two exceptions in it regarding its songwriting, as "City of Stars" and "Fools Who Dream" are excellently written and stand out among the movie's mostly generic lyrical pieces. The instrumental soundtrack, however, is a different story, and is excellent all throughout. Unfortunately, two good songs and great instrumentals are not enough to get a musical going and need good choreography to lift it all up. The slow camera pans, while difficult to do, as it means the scene needs to be taken in one cut, is an overused effect that actually harms the movie rather than benefit it. This effect is one reason why the movie's musical sections feel bland, taking away some energy that could've been gained by having extra camera angles and it is worsened by being used in every scene in the movie, instead of saving it for the slower, more impactful moments. I understand that the effect was to further the Broadway feeling, but then the choreography should've been better to make up for it.

All in all, La La Land could've been better. I've taken a half star off the movie for the bland feel and gave the movie a lot of credit for the poetic visuals. The movie has a slow start, but makes up for it with a well executed ending that effectively demonstrates the movie's great sense of imagination and the symbolism that not many movies can do.

In La La Land the "City of Angels" is reimagined through the glorious sheen of the late 40s/early 50s Hollywood musical. For examples, watch An American in Paris, Singin' in the Rain, or The Band Wagon to see what I mean. What makes Chazelle's 3rd feature so incredible is how brilliantly he understand how to reference history. He skillfully recontextualizes the vernacular of the American musical for the modern age. The exquisite score by Justin Hurwitz, elaborate production design by David Wasco, those costumes by Mary Zophres, the Technicolor, the romance - La La Land's aesthetic borrows from history but the time period and the characters are rooted firmly in contemporary society. 2016 is all here: cell phones, Hybrid vehicles, the part-time job as a barista. Chazelle makes our present era seem so much more magical. There is an exuberant quality I haven't seen recently.  Mia and Sebastian radiate sweetness too. This uncorrupted pair shares a purity. You want them to be together. Their emotion is real. You fall in love. This why we go to the cinema. If I may paraphrase a famous expression once said by Humphrey Bogart, La La Land is the stuff that [movies] are made of. It is sublime.

"La La Land" is grand. Not as good as Chazelle's "Whiplash" from a couple years ago, but still a near immaculately made film from a technical standpoint. Can't really find a tangible gripe for it, so I guess that means it's one worth recommending.

My main hiccup with this movie is that it is completely safe. This is a movie that clearly aims for "Best Picture" heights, because nothing is quite so ingratiating to Hollywood than a movie about Hollywood. Especially when this "La La Land" in question is presented with virtually no flaws or corruption. I understand that the film is doing this intentionally, and that the whole idea of the aesthetic is to bring back visions of the Gene Kelly golden age of Hollywood musicals. And to that end, the film is executed with near-perfect precision. But I could not help but keep thinking back to "Whiplash" and how bold that film was both in presentation and the statements it was making. This film is likewise about never giving up on dreams, and the more realistic, non-coruscating elements which bookend the film promise a real payoff on that front. But the majority of the movie's main body is so concerned with getting just the right lighting, just the right dance moves, and just the right timing that much of the blood, sweat and tears that come along with that promise are cast aside. 

This is a movie that simultaneously knows exactly what it wants to be and yet flirts with something dingier and more poignant. And my admittedly personal tastes almost always respond more to the latter. So for me, this film is a technical marvel that objectively deserves all of its accolades from a purely cinematic place of critique, but it just doesn't have anything truly original or memorable to say. And that is disheartening, because Damien Chazelle might just be the most talented person in movies today. I just hope he continues to push himself and his audience into more groundbreaking territory in the future.

La La Land is a perfect romance between modern film and the overwhelming charm only seen in classic films before my time.

You can tell me all day long about how Stone is breathy, Gosling looks at his feet when he dances, I don't care. A few weeks later, I went in for another show time because I was worried I wasn't in a stable mental state the first time around. I cried (slightly) less in my second showing, but it still felt as connected. Flat out it was a beautifully shot, exciting, catchy frolic through every young dreamer's fantasy in LA. 9.8/10

I confess I don't pay much attention to movie buzz or awards shows. Sometimes, this leads to surprises, such as when I left the theater of one of the worst movies I've seen in a year, only to near-literally run face-first into the promotional cutout for La La Land, gilded with rave-review quotes and blaring award nomination claims.

I have been mystified ever since. La La Land is awful. Just awful. It's not even good at what it tries to be; not a single song from the movie stuck with me the moment the last note faded. Ostensibly a throwback to the Good Old Days (ugh), it only manages to succeed in that respect by virtue (read: detriment) of its hideous whiteness. It's just... 

Okay, you know what? Let's just get into it.
Mia (played by the usually delightful Emma Stone) is an aspiring actress, living with a bunch of disposable women so unimportant they only exist to unconvincingly suggest Mia is white-people-version-of-struggling financially, and to sing an instantly-forgettable song about Mia prostituting herself at a Showbiz Industry Party on the chance someone might notice her, then disappear and are never heard from again. Which is fitting, since Mia is similarly a barely two-dimensional prop for the men behind (and in front of) the cameras.
Not that we believe Mia is struggling; she works as a barista for the rich and famous, right in the rosy-pink cornhole center of Peckerwood, Crackerfornia. (Seriously, this movie couldn't get any whiter.)

Sebastian (played by the perpetually sleepy-eyed, yet usually likable Ryan Gosling) lives alone (in a place he couldn't afford) because nobody could possibly like this self-satisfied, pretentious douchebag. He's also broke (see above, re: couldn't afford), because he keeps getting fired for being a self-satisfied, pretentious douchebag. We're supposed to sympathize with him because reasons. They actually give a reason, but it's a stupid one, because this prick should have been fired long before he proved what a pompous tool he is by demanding his version of purity.

Whaddya mean, "purity", you ask? What, is he a jazz fan or something? OF COURSE HE'S A JAZZ FAN. What other kind of music could such a strident, humorless, unlikeable asshole possibly take mortally seriously than the music of pretentious hacks and dilettantes? Oh, and he plays it, too, because duh. Jazz is the music of frustrated mediocrity. But I won't hold that against the movie.
I digress. 
It also doesn't help that he's another white knight - emphasis on the white - trying to save The Blah People from themselves, as amply demonstrated when he inexplicably lands a paying gig with a jazz-ish-sorta-not-exactly-inspired fusion band, led, of course, by one of those silly black people who ruin good music, natch. How brave to put a whitewashed spin on the norm; we've *never* seen that before. Where would black people be, without savior-douche Sebastian to reverse-Pat Boone them?

So. Mia and Sebastian (Goddess Eris, even his *name* is intolerable) meet and like each other for no reason just because without explanation apropos of nothing inexplicably something something script. Not before Sebastian is a complete dick to Mia, of course. Then they sing together about how safe it is to walk around their heavily-policed, lily-white neighborhood in the middle of the night in Los Angeles. Look, I know I'm hitting the race thing pretty hard, but in my defense, they started it.

There's absolutely no tension in Mia's so-quickly-dispelled-it-never-existed resistance to Sebastian's super-winning "charms" (Does he pinch his ham flower so hard it could cut a railroad spike in half when Emma says she doesn't like jazz? Duh-DOY. Does he aggressively browbeat her until she says she's wrong out of sheer exhaustion? Stop asking stupid questions). Nobody in the entirety of existence believes they won't get together. IT'S IN THE MOVIE POSTER, for crying out loud. Put your lame attempts at tension somewhere you haven't already given away the resolution.

So, anyway, they have a relationship while I nodded off during a salad-days montage. Seriously, I dozed for about five minutes during this. Blah blah blah, forty excruciating minutes of Sebastian looking constipated because he's getting rich and famous by playing music people actually like, and then Mia and Sebastian have their clockwork, by-the-numbers, Big Scary Fight right on cue, and naturally, it makes no sense, with Mia and Sebastian emoting because the script says so, and not because what they're saying or doing would be upsetting. "You want me to be HAPPY?!? THAT MAKES ME ANGRY! GRRR!" (I'm not kidding; that was a key point in their argument.)

Then follows another chance for me to take a nap, so at least there's that, while something something montage. Mia becomes rich and famous, because of course she does, despite the movie taking great pains to paint her as eminently mediocre at best. Sebastian ditches that awful black man and his soulless cultural appropriation of true, pure white aryan jazz, and starts his dream nightclub nobody would ever be interested in going to, which is of course standing-room-only filled with who-the-hipster-knows, because GAWD, what a hellhole of excrement-reeking pretentiousness and awful music. Must be a front for a meth lab or something.

Then there's a montage, because of course there is. Then it ends an hour and a half too late. I won't spoil the ending, because there isn't one. Nobody learns or grows, white people succeed because of course they do, and the movie writer and a few other douchenozzles hose their shorts because jazz is awesome and not at all a dissonant, pointless, masturbatory exercise in self-congratulatory, Grateful Dead-level dicking around on instruments for musicians who were never talented enough to play music with any meaning. The End.

At least they got the name right, because La La Land is the only place this supermassive rusty bullet hole of a movie could possibly be considered good, let alone so amazingly, gloriously, fabulously scrumtrulescent that Hollywood has no choice but to explode in an auto-rimming, self-congratulatory orgasm of--

Ohhhhhh. NOW I get it.

La La Land is a 2016 musical drama film directed by Damien Chazelle, of Whiplash fame, starring Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone. The film follows Seb and Mia, two people with big dreams who meet and fall in love in the city of angels, L.A. Having won seven Golden Globes, the most Golden Globes won by a film, I had big expectations for the it. And I'm happy to report, I was not disappointed! 

The film's two stars are truly wonderful, having both won Golden Globes for their roles. Ryan Gosling plays Sebastian, a down on his luck Jazz musician who dreams of opening his own Jazz club. Emma Stone plays an aspiring actress waiting for her big break. After a few chance encounters and musical numbers, romance blossoms for the two dreamers. Gosling and Stone's chemistry is incredible and really makes the film what it is. Their own singing and dancing in the film, while not perfect really adds a sense of realism, making the characters a lot more relatable. Special shoutout to J.K. Simmons, having played an asshole teacher in Chazelle's previous film and now playing an asshole bar owner. It's impossible not to enjoy his skills! 

Chazelle, only 31 years old, directed the film masterfully and has shown himself to be incredibly talented, winning, you guessed it, a Golden Globe for the film! The cinematography is beautiful providing some stunning backdrops for the romantic couple as they dance away. One of my favourite aspects of the film was the use of incredibly creative transitions between scenes. Never before have I turned to my friends during the film just to talk about screen transitions but Chazelle's creativity shines through here. He's definitely a director to look out for if you weren't already! 

Being a musical, the soundtrack is a key part of the film. The songs written for the film are certainly no let down, with the huge musical number opening the film and more serene throughout being very reminiscent of 50s musicals sick as Singin in the Rain. My personal favourite numbers would be Another Day of Sun and Someone in the Crowd. The film does an excellent job of providing 50s nostalgia such as the 'Cinemascope' opening and colourful costumes and sets. 

The ending of the film is admittedly a little unexpected and jarring. It's certainty emotional and really drives home some interesting messages about following your dreams. The film, especially the ending, is best summed up the same way Seb describes Jazz: "It's conflict and it's compromise. And it's very, very exciting". 

Overall, the film is wonderfully crafted and a whole lot of fun. It's a real feel good film and just makes you feel like dancing. I definitely recommend it and expect to hear a lot more success from the film when the Oscars roll around. I'll certainly be singing its praises!

A beautiful story about dreamers. The ones that want to be more and do more. With a great cast and a stunning original score, La La Land proves the films of old are not gone and still have a place in modern cinema.

While I appreciate the throw-back references to old Hollywood and the highly stylized look that gives it the feel of an older film, this movie overall was underwhelming. I'm amazed at the number of movie critics who thought this story was refreshing or original. One Girl Who's Not Too Far in La La Land to See How It's Off-Beat

After Sunday's mix-up at the Oscars many of you may be wondering how valid Moonlight's win is. I'm here to tell you that it is just. La La Land was truly a great film and they deserved to hold that Oscar, but it wasn't so great that they deserved to keep it.

I grew up watching movies from the golden age of musicals and studied them in my ballroom dancing days to fine-tune my performance of numbers paying homage to the classics. So when critics began saying La La Land resurrected the musical genre I walked into the theater expecting to be taken to my happy place. 

I was disappointed when I was brought in and out of my nostalgic paradise by clunky and contrived transitions into and out of musical numbers, effectively categorizing each scene as either a musical or a drama. As enchanting as the movie is, it is impossible for an audience to be swept off their feet during the mess that is trying to dance with two partners.

The first, and most off-putting partner change is just after the elaborate and large opening number set in an LA traffic jam. The music and dance come to a screeching halt as our main characters, Mia and Sebastian, have their meet-cute where they exchange a honk, a finger and a glare.
 
The audience is forced to abruptly switch partners multiples times as we watch Mia and Sebastian repeatedly run into each other and try to suppress their increasingly romantic feelings, which leads us to the now iconic number in front of the LA city scape. The least coordinated change of partner happens in this scene when Mia sits down, removes her heels and changes into tap shoes. Now, it is my humble opinion that the only person allowed to change costuming on camera is Mister Rogers but keep in mind that our neighbor intentionally did it to signify the beginning and end of something. 

In any case, our tedious tango between drama and musical continues as we watch Mia and Sebastian succumb to love and watch how their relationship is affected by the progression of their individual Hollywood careers. 

A seamless plot isn't everything in a musical; the choreography and music are important aspects to consider. Unfortunately, these aspects step on each other's toes in La La Land. The music would build to a dramatic climax while our main characters were in the middle of their 3rd set of pas de bourree's, making it seem as though the dances were originally choreographed to a different song.

The misstep between the music and the choreography has nothing to do with the score. Justin Hurwitz deserved the Oscar for Best Original Music Score by creating a beautifully whimsical yet melancholy soundtrack that perfectly encompasses the story of one's first great love.
 
The actors are also not to blame for La La Lands shortcomings. Emma Stone was captivating in this role which was reflected in her Oscar win for her performances as Mia. As a pair, Emma and Ryan Gosling (Sebastian) delivered an emotionally captivating performance that every person who's had a great love can relate to.

La La Land's two left feet belong to Director, Damien Chazelle, who failed to put as much energy into the flow of the film as he did every other aspect. Having received the Oscar for Best Director, Chazelle probably feels pretty satisfied with La La Land since it has all the technical components of the genre. But without proper transitioning it is overtly contrived, a critique he also received for his 2014 film 'Whiplash'. 

All things considered, if a passion of romantic movies is what's leading you toward La La Land, it is a must see. The cinematography, music and acting will take you on a journey reflective of your own first great love. But if you're wanting a polished musical, know that the hard-to-get flirting between musical and drama will leave you frustrated when the two never hook-up.

This movie wanted to be a masterpiece and failed. Honestly, as entertaining as Ryan and Emma are, singing is anything but their forte. Can they stay on key? yeah. Can they sing well? nope. It felt too much like the movie was playing during an open-mic karaoke night. Honestly, I could have let that slide, if it weren't for the ridiculous insipidness of the curt wrap-up ending that had no story development  at all. A couple that declares their eternal love for another is the end of one scene. The next thing, it's 5 years later--the two of them are no longer together, she's married to a guy we've never seen and she has a young child. The audience had already been informed that she would be in rehearsal for 3 months and then in Paris for 4 months. Last time I checked, 7 months is only just over half a year and if she really was in love with Gosling's character, why would all of that have just suddenly disappeared in less than a year??? Other romantic movies have successfully pulled off the failed love story--Annie Hall and The Way We Were are great examples that come to mind. But these movies made it a major point of their story's development to show how two people who deeply love each other cannot ultimately share their lives together. This movie failed to do this on any level. If the producers of this film thought that turning the classic movie-musical on its head with a sad ending would be new and praise worthy, they clearly forgot about West Side Story, Moulin Rouge, and Sweeney Todd. Ultimately, I just felt like this movie had a lot to deliver, and it just couldn't do it.

Spoiler Review
I went to see La La Land yesterday. I have to say the singing was average. Emma Stone started off with a weak, aspirate sound, and developed a fuller tone in the middle of "Here's to the One's Who Dream." I am leery about Hollywood musicals because they get people who are amateur singers that look good. At least they should dub them with professional singers like they did in My Fair Lady. At least that would have really earned the award for Best Picture. I'm sorry, Ryan Gossling is an incredible actor, and man he played that piano, and yet he needs to work on his singing voice. "City of Stars" is too low for him. He sounded like Russell Crowe in Les Mis.
The writing is cliche and garbage. In fact one of the girls in the movie makes fun of the story itself. The music makes the film pop. I loved the jazz, and the chorus numbers, yet the two main songs were not very good. This film is not a musical. It's a fantasy film with musical numbers, yet the music does not flow through the movie. The dichotomy between acting and music divides the main characters rather than uniting them, until the dream sequence. Why not just end it on that note? The dream sequence added a David Lynch vibe, as if the dream were reality and the two characters were in a five year bitter sweet nightmare. If it had ended on the dream sequence then the movie would have been genius, almost equal to Mullholland Drive, or Inland Empire. Yet they take the nostalgic way and we get a cliche ending. Over all I give this film a whopping 8/10.

With a fantastic direction, a beautiful photography, lively and catchy musical performances, a colorful production design, passionate acting performances and a simple yet wonderful story, La La Land is a complete hit. A classical musical for the modern age, this film is not a perfect and romantic story, is a film for dreamers. Is a classic musical set in the real world, with real and flawed people, not perfect singers and dancers that also happen to be the perfect couple. This is a hopeful film, so needed after the crappy year that was 2016, and that is one of the thigns I like the most about it. And its hopeful without turning into a Disney movie. It's for the new generations, where the people prefer to develop professionally than to sacrifice everything for love. This movie masterfully combines a soul of the past with a mentality of the present and, because of that, it's a complete hit and a modern classic.

Though I am in a severe minority on this one, I was not particularly taken in by La La Land's narrative. It was very mediocre in a year impactful, hard-hitting pictures. I can't even say it's my favorite musical of the year. I'll give you a moment to take that one in.

Overall, it's a nice, original movie, with an adequate cast, full of very good (and also original) music, but it's been strangled and clubbed to death with 50's and 60's filmmaking techniques. It lost its realness trying to breathe life into a long gone genre. In my opinion, a movie has done its job, if it made you feel something, but all I was left at the end of this movie was the feeling that it wasn't made for me, or the audience, but the 60 year old voters of the Academy. The 93% rating is definitely misleading, I would say, in reality, it's probably somewhere around 80-85%.

My problem with La La Land

I will start with what captivated me about Chazzelle's film.  The LA scenery, particularly the scene where Gosling and Stone are walking to their cars and they perform the tap number (seeing them physically change shoes for the routine was particularly cute).  The long takes.  Wow!  Such impressive hard work.  Really, hard work sums up the impression of what has been done in this picture.  Okay! Time to complain.  
La La Land got the most nominations at this year's Golden Globes, and won ALL OF THEM.  I do not think the movie is bad, but comparing it to it's competitors, I feel beat when it wins.  La La Land - the name invites itself to witnessing fantasy as something not attainable, or if it is, pointless and gotten by chance.  Gosling is a jazz piano player, and Stone is an actress, and their characters are written as if they've been described by a sub-par television character performed by my favorite actor, Gael Garcia Bernal, that "they perform with the blood", and we're expected to accept that and follow the kiddie pool plot.
  La La - dreaming... it is what their aspirations are for the first part of the film.  The movie is broken up into Winter, Spring, Summer, Fall, and 5 years later.  The seasons appear for no other purpose than to show a brief change in time.  Throughout that year in northern hemisphere exposure to the sun,  we see the leads going from embarrassing auditions and economic hardships, to giddy romance, to achieving their dreams, losing their romance, and feeling sad about it.  Sigh.  I have no idea what happened during summer.Even movie stars feel sad?  Not all that glitters is gold?  No, I'm sure there's more to it that that, but the movie blankets itself in cliches so that the plot is easy to follow - we know the story is fantasy, the characters... it's no shock to me I have no idea what their names are, they were written for the . bankability of Stone's not completely there grace within earnest gumption, and Gosling's stand in front of a voiceless band of black jazz performers, and tell you what jazz is about talents, white hollywood heartthrob talents.
What's upsetting about the takeaway of awards in the acting category is not the performances.  Stone's eagerness, if not exactly moving, is at least infectious, but it is nowhere near her dualistic exude your world, and slink away performance of a recovering drug addict in Birdman.  Gosling's performance I can say less positive things for.  Most of what we think we feel from his character comes from the movie's score as he plays the piano (which I read was in fact him!), head down.  This also pales considerably against his richer work with Derek Cranfrance.  Most of Stone's real competition is in the Drama category of Globes (Portman is all things Jackie Kennedy in Pablo Loraine's 2nd best film of the year.  Ruth Negga, despite a script that's attempts for realism I'm sure writes a much more quiet portrayal of it's characters than their real life counterparts, still makes the best with it's quiet moments.  Amy Adams carries the sci-fi thriller, Arrival, and bridges the genre gap to the melodrama audience of Lifetime fair).  But it's sad to see that this minimally fleshed out character won against 20th Century Women's Dorthea, played by Annette Bening.  The focus of 20th Century Women is of a son trying to figure out his mom, getting deep and sparking insights, that burn out without reaching a conclusion to his quest.  This performance of a woman too mysterious to capture, is captivatingly performed by an actress who gets to shine brighter and more centered than she ever has in a movie, and who has been too often overlooked (for Hilary Swank).  That performance lost to that of a character whose big revealing backstory for when we got bac to her hometown was that she really always wanted to be an actress.  Oh,the power of showing someone persistently reach for their dreams, has on a group of Americans, or film makers I suppose.
	A movie can be more than the sum of its two-dimensional characters.  I can allow it that much patience.  I can respect how the figures on the screen are placed into position, and audience expectations that allow us to see that la la, dreaming, can look many different ways to the same person simultaneously and at different times.  The last scene in particular showed us a fantasy with a  completely different font and filter than what we had been seeing, and it was effective in how differently it appeared, but how utterly still not reality.  What holds this story back is how little it understands the richness , and variety to reality.
One more rant, I already mentioned it, and it's a popular critique, but really?  Ryan Gosling is going to save pure jazz?  The corruptor is John Legend?  The film acknowledges jazz's roots and dominant sourcing in the black community by the majority of silent black players in its jazz scenes, but gives that little bar a white messiah.  Now, I understand racial typecasting and stereotyping shouldn't reserve roles, but they didn't consider challenging those when casting their charming leads of their musical.
Look, I know I personally care about these awards more than I should.  But many people do.  What we watch is important.  Yes, from the rest of our nominees it's clear that this Oscars is not #sowhite.  But it says something when brilliant white showmanship get the spotlight, and gay black boys, and strong women who had to wait still stand in the shadow.  What is it about showmanship that lets us forgive all shortcomings and sins?

Genuinely enchanting, technically irreprehensible and masterfully orchestrated, La La Land revels in a wave of Hollywood nostalgia. Hardly any other Oscar nominee this year could surpass it in regards to unadulterated entertainment and crowdpleasing buoyance. This might result in its main fault: for all its gloss and heart, there's hardly any challenge for the audience, or even tangence of a darker undercurrent. Nonetheless, and even despite original music that rarely hits the high note of Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling's riveting performances, it excels.
Certainly lived up to the hype. The ending was perfect: one moment that said everything.
I give this a 92/-A.

I'm not a very big fan of Musicals, and it's one of the only genres that I don't really care for. There have been a few exceptions, though. Grease is one of my favorite movies of all time, and Westside Story is a classic. There were many supporters of this musical, and I was interested when I saw the praise it was getting and for the team behind the film. Damien Chazelle made one of my favorite movies a few years ago with Whiplash, and this looked like it could be almost as good. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone have proven to be a perfect pair in past films, so this film was bound for success. This movie may have changed my mind about Musicals as a whole after watching it. Every musical number starting with the opening scene was jaw-dropping, and the choreography was absolutely amazing. The performances were all there and the direction from Chazelle is as good as it gets. One of the biggest peeves that I have about the film; though, is that the wonderful J.K. Simmons is hardly used and I was disappointed in that. Alas, there are many things to love about this film, and it will go down as one of the greatest Musicals in history when it's all said and done.
Beautifully done, technically phenomenal, but it didn't move me like it seems to have moved others.

Here's to the fools who dream, Damien Chazelle has done it again. La La Land is beautifully directed with a message many films have never sent to the audience. Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling, the leads in this masterpiece, perform their roles in the best possible way. Both of their ambitions and dreams feel so real, specifically Sebastian's love for jazz. It breathed much needed life back into a forgotten genre with breathtaking dancing and singing sequences. Each musical sequence feels seamlessly woven with the story. The dancing and singing feels like a natural continuation of the scene already taking place. This film is not only very well directed, but it also centralizes on the idea that we must pursue our dreams, even if it means sacrificing the things we love.

It may be new to younger folks, but if you follow musical history one realizes that this film is a mediocre MGM musical-say something that might star June Allyson and Peter Lawford. Good actors, but not good singers or dancers. The director had good intentions, but the execution was a disappointment. The opening scene was especially disappointing--the actors could not even lip sync correctly. Music was ok, but not great. I could not even remember a song as I left the theater. Too bad, as I though the director's previous effort in "Whiplash" was very good.
This entertaining film is extremely well executed and is a fresh take on the musical. While the story is familiar, the characters are likable and (most) the music is enjoyable.

La La Land is a musical that is written and directed by Damien Chazelle and stars Emma Stone and my man Ryan Gosling.
So a while back in mid-2016 I was scrolling through my YouTube recommendations desperately searching for a new trailer for Suicide Squad (The hype was real) when I came across a trailer for a movie called La La Land. Now of course I knew next to nothing about this movie accept from the fact that it stars Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone as the main characters, oh and it's musical. So after that I pretty much just ignored nearly all the marketing for this movie, then I heard that it had been nominated for 30 awards. That and my mom was desperate to see it. So when it came out in the local theatre I used my pocket money to pay for both of us to go see this movie and my god... this movie is AMAZING!!!!
I'm not even kidding here this is one of the greatest films I have ever seen not just out of all the movies I saw in 2016 but one of the greatest films I've seen in years. This is coming from a guy who is really not a fan of musicals but his film was just the literal definition perfection.
There are 2 things that full on deserve praise weather you love or hate the movie. The camera work, the camera work in this movie is just phenomenal; there are so many times in this movie where you will be thinking how the heck they shot that scene. There are some beautiful shots in this movie that literally made my heart skip a couple of beats L,A is just stunning in this movie I loved the way it was shot. All the musical numbers are shot with long extensive shots with some with literally no jump cuts at all, which leads me to the choreography. Holy spagbowl!!! The choreography in this movie is so well done, most of these musical numbers are shot with almost no jump cuts there just long extensive and brilliantly filmed shots, the actors are literally dancing and singing for the entirety of the songs so that in affect is almost 3 minutes and these dance sequences unfold seamlessly. There is one incredible sequence where Gosling and Stone dance in front of an L, A sunset and it's just incredible. And yes the musical numbers as you can imagine are very energetic and really fun to watch.  And that is partly due to excellent directing which I'll talk more about in just a second. The set design just adds to the visual beauty of the film. I loved the films use of vibrant and colourful backgrounds at the right moments and everything else from the way the scenes were lit was just amazing.
Pretty much all the songs from this movie have been stuck in my head since Thursday which is when I saw this film. There're that good. I honestly haven't really heard any other songs in a musical that are similar to the ones in this film they're just so unique and memorable. 
Damien Chazelle's directing is up there in my top 5. I'm not even joking it's that good. The way he movies the camera in this movie alone is incredible. He tried his absolute best with this movie and it paid off tremendously and the same could be said for the script, the Chezelle's script for this movie might just be one of my favourite Screen plays of all time. This is backed up by some brilliant performance.
Ryan Gosling as usual is fantastic. I really liked how the film explored this character's passion for Jazz, you really feel for this character because he's a very passionate piano player and he can't play what he wants to play because he keeps ending up with jobs where he ends up playing Christmas songs at loads of different restaurants.  A lot of his Jokes landed really well, I really like it when you have someone who has one of the straightest faces and have him be the funniest characters and it works so well in this movie.
Emma stone is also great in this movie. Her performance never faltered during the entirety of the films run time. Her character is very sympathetic, she's actress trying to break into the film industry and every attempt at that point really doesn't go well for her but she keeps trying. In that leads me to my favourite part of this movie.
I absolutely loved the romance between these 2 characters. Their romance was just so touching and as well as making for most of the films funniest moments but it felt genuine and surprisingly unpredictable. A lot of romances I see these days feel very predictable and at times clichéd which is something that I criticised the film Passengers for. But this film was just unpredictable with the way it handled the romance which I thought was really refreshing 
La La Land is at it's a core a love letter to people who are passionate about what they do, people who dream who will never stop trying to fulfil that dream, the people who want to succeed in doing what they love, someone is going to do exactly that no matter what people think of them will plot ahead. That's who this movie is aimed at. This movie is in a way grabbing anyone passionate by the shoulders and telling them to go fulfil their dreams. This movie genuinely wants people to fulfil their dreams and I really have to point out this movie is actually made by someone who clearly feels that he has done exactly that and is trying to encourage other people to do the same thing.
I really loved this films message because I'm personally at a stage in my life where I really want to fulfil my dreams and pretty much become successful at what I love doing and what I want to do in the future. And I feel like this film got the message out their better than anything I have really seen before.
And this message is told through fantastic musical numbers that never once got annoying, every time someone started singing it felt like it was just a natural progression of the film it never really felt like it was someone going "hey this is the part where we sing" it just felt natural which is something I usually only feel in animated movies, this movie just has such a real feeling to it.  
La La Land is one of the best films I've ever seen, I seriously recommend you get check this movie out guys I'm telling you it will be one of the greatest movie theatre experiences of your life.
